Name: Scrabble: Pirates of the Caribbean Edition
Description: This is the same version of Scrabble you would find in any toy store, but this version includes round tiles, and a variant where you can prevent your opponent from taking her turn.  One tile is placed on a special space on the edge of the board, and if you can place a word using that tile, you can cause your opponent to lose a turn.

Name: Test Cricket Game
Description: This game was played by children during the War. Game comes with instructions on the lid, a miniature wooden cricket bat and ball, wickets, a scoreboard  and 4 wooden players.

Name: Daily Mail Footer-Pool
Description: The box of this Chad Valley game from 1950 says that this is a thrilling novelty game and is not a pool solver. Cover features famous football "soccer" players from the times.

Name: Richesses de France
Description: The goal of the game is to complete a circuit in France (wine, economic, city tours, or specialties) faster than your opponents by traveling from city to city.  This is done either by foot, bicycle, or car.  Money can be earned (to buy a bicycle or car) or lost during the game.

Name: Brooklands Automobile Racing Game
Description: CHAD VALLEY BROOKLANDS Automobile Racing Game which features 6 lead racing cars and a very pretty track with all kinds of areas on it that cause special circumstances to happen.

Name: High Speed Test: Dunlop Tyre Racing Game
Description: CHAD VALLEY Dunlop Tyre Racing Game called HIGH SPEED TEST... The first part of the game you travel around each department of the Dunlop Tire Company where you manufacture tires. Then in the second part of the game you test those tires on the race track, The game has a built in spinner and comes with 3 lead racing cars. The board has a nice picture illustration of the Dunlop Factory in its center.

Name: Motor Delivery Game
Description: Die driven race game from Chad Valley. Games comes with 4 lead racing cars, a die and a game board. The object of the game is to be the first one to deliver a new motor vehicle to town.

Name: Tree Top Targets game
Description: Chad Valley shooting game which comes with a cork rifle and cellulose targets that look like Christmas Balls on a tree.

Name: Stolen Treasure
Description:
From the publisher's website:

Diamonds, bonds, gems, art classics and money are up for grabs in this new test of spy and intrigue. Each asset requires a special set of tools to successfully heist the treasure. Once a player successfully acquires a treasure, the goal is to avoid the CIA and thieves to capture the most points and victory.

Name: Game: The Gaming
Description:
Game: the Gaming is a non-collectible card game for two to six players in which you play some of the Big RPG Companies, all struggling to churn out new product and rake in as much profit as you can from rehashed old concepts and tired system mechanics. The trick is to latch onto hot new concepts and milk them for all they're worth before the ever-fickle target audience (predominantly males age 12-22) either turn to the next new thing or have to find a real job and move out of mom's basement.

G:tG is a general spoof of the entire Gaming industry, and should be taken entirely for the good-hearted fun that it is (especially by any of the aforementioned Big Gaming Companies who may have Big Legal Teams...).

Name: Tru Action Electric Baseball Game
Description: TRU Action Electric Baseball game by Tudor featured a spring loaded bat and a magnet that was used as a ball. The pitching device threw the ball at a target which stood upright behind the batters side of the field. on that target was BALL. STRIKE and WILD PITCH. Once the "ball was thrown at the "plate" the batter sitting behind the wall which was the plate used the spring loaded bat to strike the target plate hitting the ball in the air and on to the playing field where a number of circles were marked. Hitting the ball into a circle was an out. Little men similar to those used in vibrating football games of the same ilk were used as base runners and "ran around the bases once the power was turned on. A "fence or wall" was also situated after the outfield and any hit "ball that stuck to the wall higher than the fence was a HOME RUN.

Name: UNO: Doctor Who
Description:
Another themed variation on the classic card game.

Features 15 character cards representing heroes, villains and iconic imagery from the Dr Who series. Play along with The Doctor, Cybermen, Daleks, the Tardis and more. Includes 112 cards for 2-10 players. With fully molded and decorated Dalek collectors card case.

WHAT MAKES IT DIFFERENT FROM TRADITIONAL UNO: The "Exterminate" card - when played, the player holding the lowest number of cards immediately has to draw 4 cards from the deck.
Families: Versions & Editions: Versions with IP after the original release

Name: Dawson City Barbers
Description:
From the box:

The Gold Rush has hit Dawson City. Thousands descend on the once barren location for the chance for fortune and glory. Gold emerges from the streams, and hair grows from the head. A fortune is available in both gold and hair. Only the most savvy barbers will earn a fortune through cutting hair, training, and panning for gold.

Name: Church Ball: The Game
Description: Church Ball The Game is a game for two players or two teams based on the LDS movie of the same name. Players attempt to score baskets by rolling the dice and using cards which modify the dice rolls.

Name: Druthers
Description:
Druthers is an LDS game for two or more players. Players share their opinions using phrases such as, "If I had my druthers..."

From the publisher: Everyone likes to be asked their opinion, but how often does a seven-year-old (or even her dad) get to tell what she thinks? In this easy-to-play game, her choice can become the right answer! Simple, everyday questions have four given answers and a fifth "fill in your own" answer. Questions are geared to people in four categories: family, young child, teenage, or general. Players get points for correctly predicting "others' druthers." Some questions bring hilarious responses; others might be insightful or thought-provoking. You'll discover things you have in common with all LDS families and what may be unique to your own household.

Name: Speak It Not
Description:
Speak It Not is an LDS game in which players attempt to reveal mystery words without using words that are not allowed. It is similar to the games Password and Taboo.

From the publisher: Speak It Not is an exciting, fast-paced card game for Latter-day Saints. Players divide into teams and take turns describing a mystery word without using that word or five other "forbidden" words listed on the drawn card. So if the mystery word is Nephi, the player who drew the card prompts teammates to guess the word without saying Lehi, Brass Plates, Laman, Lemuel, or Brother. Beware: hand gestures, sound effects, abbreviations, or rhyming words are also not allowed! More than 400 cards are included, with mystery words from the Book of Mormon, Bible, Church history, and Church culture. There is no limit on the number of people who can play, which makes Speak It Not the perfect game for family home evenings, parties, or Church activities.

Name: Hop-Scotch
Description: From the makers of Pass-Out comes another drinking game that doesn't necessarily require alcohol to be enjoyed.  Players roll move around the board to collect letters spelling H O P S C O T C H G A M E with the first player to do so becoming the winner. Many of the spaces landed on will require players to take a drink.

Name: Timestalk
Description:
From the rulebook:

"TIMESTALK is a board game for 4 to 6 players, Ages 14 and up.  Approximate playing time is 1 1/2 to 2 hours.
TIMESTALK is a race game (the first player to advance through the "four ages", achieve a successful launch, past the Black Hole and directly into the "arrow of outer space" wins the game), but the race is HUMAN and so the path to success is long and arduous, marked by crises, aggressions, precautions and risk-taking.
Interface all of this with the unpredictable consequences of Timewarps and a Black Hole and you have "A SPACE AGE GAME FOR HUNTERS AND GATHERERS".

Name: My House
Description:
Taken from the Opstelten Speelgoed website.

Where are the toothbrushes to be found at your house? Do they belong in the kitchen, the bathroom or maybe in both? And what about your toys? Do they belong in the Living room or in your bedroom? In any case not in the bathroom. Then they better be stored in the attic. With the game My House children can playfully tell how things are organized at their home. It’s all about telling about their experiences from home. Becoming aware of the arrangement of things at home and thus familiar in their own house.

It is interesting and fun to hear for the parents, hearing their children talk about how they think about the arrangements at home. The children for their part become very resourceful in substantiating their ideas about the location of the objects. But My House offers even more. The older children can play memory games with it or call forth all their linguistic skills in a game of “Linguistic Happy Families”. Thus the game co-develops along with the development of the linguistic skills of the child. Ranging from story telling up to in their own words finding synonyms to complete their set of “Happy Families”!

Name: Het Piratenspel
Description:
From the Opstelten Speelgoed website:

The story starts hundreds of years ago. The oceans and seas are controlled by pirates. This is also the case in this game. Beware, or pirates will steel your gold coins, even before you have made your first move towards finding the treasure of Lame Max, the notorious pirate king of ancient times. The treasure of Lame Max was not lost when his ship was sunk. Scattered across the playing field are old coins, which you should try to gather and keep safe from competing pirates! It is your goal to retrieve most of Max’s treasure and become the next Pirate king.

The pirate game is intended to stimulate counting, comparing and playing together for children at a young age. The different game variants are constructed in such a way that the game follows the development stages of the children in the period between ages 3 and 9, for children interested in board games a crucial time. Whereas the younger players depend on a simple game structure and a relatively short playing time, they gradually develop towards a stage where they will want to have control over the game development, their progress as well as that of their opponents. In fact they desire that their own strategic insight can make the difference between winning or losing. In the most elaborate game variant the Pirate game is a challenge even for grown ups!

Name: Book of Mormon Who?
Description:
A guessing game similar to Guess Who? in which players try to identify a Book of Mormon character based on unique characteristics.

From the publisher: In this fun guessing game for the whole family, each team represents a “scripture sleuth” and must try to be the first team to identify the Book of Mormon character on the “Who?” card held by the other team. The first team to collect three of their opponents’ “Who?” cards wins the game.

Name: Dick Turpin's game of Highway Robbery
Description:
Dick Turpin's game of Highway Robbery
"A thrilling game for 2 to 6 players" from Arrow Games Ltd (A Milton Bradley Company).
The object of the game is to be the player who has collected the largest amount of Booty by the end of the game. The game ends when the Mail Coach has completed four journeys across the country.
One player takes on the role of the Crown Agent, controlling the King's Men, protecting the Mail Coach and attempting to arrest the Highwaymen. Attempting to outwit the Crown Agent (and each other) the remaining players take on the roles of the Highwaymen (chosen from Black Henry, Mathew Flood, One Eye Craven, Vulcan or Dick Turpin). 
Highwaymen can 'earn' Guineas by holding up the Mail Coach or by capturing fellow Highwaymen and collecting a ransom, whilst the Crown Agent can issue fines (or earn a few Guineas on the side by accepting Bribes) to arrested Highwaymen.

Name: Sandy Hawley's Post Time
Description:
A Canadian-made horse racing game, endorsed by champion jockey Sandy Hawley.

Game summary;
The players each start the game with the same amount of game money with which they buy horses and bet on them in 6 races.  The horse cards are dealt to the players and each player decides to buy one or more of those dealt. Horses not purchased are returned to the bank and are offered again after the first race.  The odds paid to the winning bet are determined by dealing the "odds" cards to the players' horses.  Each player may bet up to $1000 to win on horses that the player owns.  A race consists of 4 or 5 quarters.  There are 5 identical decks of "race cards" that have on their face one of the ten available horses.  For each of the quarters a "Race Card" deck is shuffled and then laid out in a row on the game board, the horse pictured on the last card is in the lead of that quarter.  The leading horse earns a bonus for the player.  The horse pictured on the last card of the last deck is the race winner.  The winning horse earns the bet times the odds for the player.  After 6 races, the horses are sold back to the bank for the original purchase price and the richest player is the game winner.

From the game box:
"The high stakes horse racing game.  Fun for the whole family!
Post Time allows a maximum of 10 horses to run in every race.
Experience the thrill of owning a racehorse, entering it in a race, and collecting the prize money.
You have a six race series in which to accumulate assets, through buying horses and betting them to win!  And, of course, your stable of winning horses can net you BIG purse money.
You don't need horseshoes to win!
A basic knowledge of horse racing is all you need to play and enjoy POST TIME.  The Tote Board provided sets the odds, purse money and payoff for each race.  Play your cards right, and you could be the 'winningest' owner at the track.
POST TIME includes:
1 Game Board
1 Tote Board
1 Set of Steward Cards
1 Set of ODDS Cards
1 Program with Rules
5 Sets of Race Cards
1 Set of Ownership Cards
POST TIME Cash"

Name: Qi Guo Xiang Qi
Description:
This "variant" of Xiangqi is played on a 19 X 19 grid (Go board). Seven armies represent the seven warring states of the late Zhou Dynasty (1045 - 221 BC):
Qin (white), Chu (red), Qi (indigo), Yan (black), Han (orange), Wei (green), Zhao (purple).

Each army is played by one player. For less than 7 players, there are several predetermined "allies", so one or more players direct two armies.

Every army has 17 pieces, which makes a total of 120, regarding the central single piece, representing the kingdom of Zhou. This piece does not move at all and cannot be captured.

Each of the armies consist of the following pieces:
1 General - moving like the Queen in modern Western Chess.
1 Deputy General - moving like the Rook in modern Western Chess.
1 Officer - moving like the Bishop in modern Western Chess.
1 Diplomat - moving like the Queen, too, but cannot capture or be captured.
1 Cannon - like the Cannon in XiangQi (moving like the Rook, but capturing over one intervening piece).
1 (Unit of) Archers - moving like the Queen, but only for 4 spaces.
1 (Unit of) Crossbowmen - moving like the Queen, but only for 5 spaces
2 (Units of) Swordsmen - moving 1 space diagonally.
4 (Units of) Broadswordsmen - moving 1 space vertically or horizontally.
4 (Units of) Cavalry - moving 4 spaces: 1 in a straight line and then 3 diagonally.

There are several rules regulating possible allies and winning conditions over single states. Residual pieces of beaten armies are removed from the board.

Simplified, it can be said, that to gain a victory over another state, a player has to capture the general or more than 10 pieces of this state. The player with the most captured pieces at the end of the game wins.

There are similarities both to Go (the central piece as the centre of the universe/representing the Zhou Dynasty, or the removing of "dead" armies) and Xiangqi  (the pieces, the armies ...); this and the 7 players make this game unique in the history of strategic boardgames.

Name: Catholic-opoly
Description:
A Catholic variant of Monopoly. Players compete to build churches, do good works, and manage their money.

From the publisher: Catholic-opoly is a creative and imaginative Catholic board game based on the principles and history of the Catholic faith.  The goal of this game is to build as many churches and cathedrals as possible in order to “help spread the word of the Lord”.  Players can learn about the history and practices of the Catholic church and read scriptures related to Biblical locations as they move about the board.  In addition, the game addresses financial management and community service as well.

Name: Mormon-Opoly
Description:
An LDS variant of Monopoly in which players compete to build churches and do good works.

From the publisher: Mormon-opoly is a creative and exciting LDS game based on the principles and history of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.  The goal of this Mormon game is to build as many chapels and stake centers as possible in order to “help build the kingdom of God”.  Players can learn about LDS church history and read related scriptures as they move about the board.  In addition, the game addresses financial management and community service as well.

Name: NewLondonAreaopoly
Description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

Typical fundraiser type Monopoly game.

Name: Mexican Pete: I Got It
Description: This is a dice rolling gambling game from Parker Brothers featuring cards with all possible die rolls on them. Rolling correct numbers results in winning bets on particular die rolls

Name: Warzon
Description:
From the rules:

Each player represents a country engaged in war.  The players begin the game with well equipped sea, air, and land forces and a war chest.  The units are moved around the board, encountering the dangers and obstacles of modern warfare.  During the play the units may seize certain strategic bases, ports, etc., allowing the player to collect a specified amount of money from opponents.

The units are safe at all times in friendly territory but may be lost or captured when they enter enemy areas.  Each player moves the units into play three at a time, one in each of air, land and sea lanes.  Players must continue to move the 3 units around the track (lowest rated move first) until all 3 units have left the playing field.  Then another 3 units are moved through the track until all players have moved all their units through the track.

The winner is the player that has earned the largest amount of assets (money + value of surviving units).

Name: Cinderella or Hunt the Slipper
Description: Hunt for the Slipper is an old game which features cards that represent the Chicago Police Department and also smaller cards that represent different things that might be missing.  Looks like the game plays like a rummy game.

Name: Empires
Description:
Based on game play mechanics Empires seems to be the precursor to games like Risk.

From the rules:

Empires is played on a world map; the individual players representing "Powers" which include; the United States, Great Britain, France, Russia, Italy and Japan.  The object is for one player to establish a World Empire and eliminate all other players from the game.

Parts include 6 pawns representing each country, 20 Markers for each player, 48 resource cards and 48 armament cards with values of 1 or 5 representing Air, Navy and Army units.

Players start in the start box and move from point to point around the world map, landing on free territories (gaining a resource card), colonies (placing a marker to control and taking resources) and blockades (if owned then 2 resources are owned to the controlling player).  Resources can be converted into armaments, 3 resources for 1 randomly drawn armament.  Once all colonies are taken a colonial war begins and as players land on opposing colonies they may choose an armament class and announce an attack. The player with the highest strength wins the battle and takes the colony.  If he loses he loses resources equal to the colonies values.

The final stage is total war when all armaments are gone.  The first player back to start challenges the other players to war and compares values for all armaments, winner take all.  Last man standing wins.

Name: Junior Combination Games
Description: This game by Milton Bradley copyrighted 1905 features a number of table games all combined in the same box. Included are India, Johny Jumps, Railroad Game, Puss in the Corner, Fortune Telling, Checkers, Covering the Pig, Steeplechase, Bicycle race, Hop, American Corners and Yacht Race. Game came with numerous Bits and pieces used as playing pieces for any of the games you might want to play.

Name: Quiz Me: Game of Numbers
Description: Milton Bradley distributed this Trivia type game in 1938. The box claims that this is "An exciting game of questions and Answers about things that everyone should know.

Name: A Game of the States
Description: A Game of States is copyrighted from 1887 by O.F. Decker M.D. Buffalo, N.Y.. The game has Geographical and Historical questions on 70 cards for a total of 700 questions. The game box states that Every question is Answered by the Name at the top of the Card. he game sold for 75 cents

Name: Hänsel und Gretel: Ein Märchenspiel
Description:
(translated: Hansel and Gretel - A Fairy Tale Game)

Probably from the 1950s.

A simple roll and move course with events from the Grimm fairy tale. The board has die-cut holes in it instead of spaces, it stays in place of the box.
On the box's edge is a short wooden lever which can be used as a stand to keep the board at a slight angle. The playing pieces are colored pottery balls which are moved from hole to hole - some holes are larger than the balls - should a die roll or an event (explained in the box's lid) bring your piece to such a hole, your ball falls through, rolls to a chute on the lower end of the board and you will have to start again. The mechanism is similar to Cat & Mice or Holes & Traps.
Families: Folk Tales & Fairy Tales: Hansel and Gretel

Name: Cat & Mice or Holes & Traps
Description:
(translated: Cat and Mice - A Fun Race)

Probably from the 1950s. A simple roll-and-move game where up to 5 players are mice (small pottery balls), trying to reach the end of a tilted course (with holes for spaces, similar to HÃ¤nsel und Gretel: Ein MÃ¤rchenspiel), one player is the cat (a larger ball), allowed to move in both directions, trying to catch all mice.

The cat never can fall through the holes, the mice can (and have to start over).

The board is raised and has a track on it. Each point along the track is a hole. Some holes are bigger than others. The playing pieces are circular, like a ball.

One player is a cat, the others are mice. Everyone moves along the track by a die roll. The mice must escape from the cat player who has a big advantage. If a mouse player lands on one of the bigger holes then it will fall through the hole and out of the game. The cat playing ball is too large to fall through a hole so he doesn't mind which space he lands on.

The cat wins if all the mice are caught or the mouse who gets to the end of the track first, wins

Name: Kreuz und quer durch den grünen Harz
Description:
(translation: Cross-country through the green Harz (a mountain region in Germany))
A simple roll-and-move game, where two groups of players each take a different route through the region (both routes have the same number of spaces and share several spaces with each other). If players reach certain spaces on the board, they have to read educational texts about the cities and villages of the region.

Name: Bombers Aloft
Description:
From the rules:

There are four lanes of travel.  The first spin selects the lane of travel.   Player 1 spins again and sets the bomber's altitude.  The nose of the bomber is placed in the metal stand provided at the height noted. A third spin gives the movement value.

The AA gun spins next (2 times to set the lane and altitude).   If they match the lane and height of the bomber it is brought down.  Each player follows in succession with a bomber and then the AA gun's attack.  If the AA score a kill it gets points based on the zone the bomber is in and its altitude.

The lanes contain spaces with numbers (from 1 to 14) that reference the hit on the score card. The value is recorded as part of the score.  Any plane that comes to a "Change Altitude" space spins the spinner for a new altitude.

The game ends when all bombers have been shot down or have reached the finish line.  The player with the largest score is the winner.

Name: Don Pipas
Description: Game of tour of order. The players must avoid all the dangers and take his(her,your) gentleman to except in the castle

Name: Tartarugas comilonas
Description: I Play of order. By means of issues of dice of colors the players must lead to the tortoises to the basket of food

Name: The Klutz Book of Card Games: for Sharks and Others
Description: The Klutz Book of Card Games for Sharks & Others is the complete Klutz-proof instructions (including diagrams, photos, cartoons, blueprints, strategy, etc.) for the best 20 card games in the galaxy! From Old Maid to Gin Rummy.

Name: Basic Fleet Combat System
Description:
Basic Fleet Combat System (BFCS) is a minimalist game of starship fleet combat, with an eye to playability.

Using simple stats for ships, simple movement rules, and quick combat rules, you can fight out simple battles between any number of ships.

Use any hex paper, Dice as indicated later on in the rules, pen & paper as needed, and some type of markers to use as ships.

Name: Basic Starship Combat System
Description:
From the game's designer:

'While I enjoy Star Fleet Battles, it seems that there has been so much added to it since I first played that it is not the game that I first played. I wanted a simple, flexible game - and I wanted to add in Construction - something never in SFB. So here we are.

'I thought about several ways to add realism to the game, and while that goal is laudable, it does not always render a usable game. While some things are in the game for realism, others are in it just for fun. One goal was realistic movement of some sort. I have tried to give a CONSISTENT movement system, at least.

'I would like to have fighters as much as the next guy, but my sense of reality would not allow them to dominate Space Warfare as much as some would prefer.'

Name: License Plate Game
Description:
License Plate Game
Games On The Go Ages 4 and up.

On their cards, players write letters from the license plates of passing cars.  As the cards fill up, players score points for every three letter word that they create.  The strategy is in deciding where on the card to put your letters to maximize your ability to create words.  (letters can not be moved once placed).  Everyone works with the same letters that drive by, so this strategy is the only thing that separates the winner from the rest.

Contents: Instructions, playing cards, pencil.

Name: Blackbeard, Bluebeard and Redbeard
Description:
Blackbeard, Bluebeard and Redbeard (aka Yet Another Pirate Themed Board Game) is based on the award-winning children's song of the same name by Eric Herman and Kenn Nesbitt. Eric Herman designed the game with the same core audience in mind as his music fans (elementary school kids and their parents).

Blackbeard, Bluebeard and Redbeard is a very lightly weighted and semi-abstract "race to get the most treasure", but it also incorporates some nice Eurogame touches, including action point movement, card combinations, minimal luck and variable victory point options.  As such, it is an excellent gateway game for younger players on the verge of discovering more involved games like Settlers and Tikal.

The game is designed in the low-cost tradition of (James Ernest's company), with pennies, nickels and dimes used for treasures, and tokens from other games used as the game pieces, and with a great amount of humor in the cards.

Blackbeard, Bluebeard and Redbeard is currently in playtesting and is expected to be available in 2008.

Name: Jack and the Beanstalk
Description:
Tagline: The Shaking, Quaking Action Game - Race Up the Beanstalk to Grab the Gold!

Once Upon A Time there was a little boy called Jack...

One day Jack planted a magic bean, which grew so high that it disappeared into the clouds. Jack climbed up from branch to branch. He climbed higher and higher, right up to the clouds - where he found a fearsome Giant guarding his treasure chest.........

To win you must climb the beanstalk twice to steal a Bag of Gold and a Golden Egg from under the giant's very nose!
Families: Folk Tales & Fairy Tales: Jack and the Beanstalk

Name: Bible Knows
Description:
The Holy Scriptures are written inside the cards with numbers. The Bible Knows cards are in order from Double 7 to Double 0.

There are 8 sets in the deck of 36 cards. The Double sets have "Bonus" points. When a player scores with a double, and connects the numbers, the player gets the regular points plus the bonus points.

You can play 150 to 1,000 points. Each player is dealt 7 cards. Whoever has the Double 7 plays first, or, if a double 5 is played first, player receives points plus bonus. The highest double goes first. If a player scores with a double you get the points plus the bonus points.

All players must quote the scripture out loud before connecting the numbers. The first player to run out of cards must say, "Bible Knows". The one who wins the hand receives all points in the other players hand except the bonus points.

Name: Disney's Dinosaur Aladar's Quest
Description: Aladar's Quest is a board game based on Disney's 2000 movie, Dinosaur. After a  flaming meteor destroys much of prehistoric earth, Aladar and his friends must race to reach their new nesting grounds. Players advance by spinning a color wheel. Rock slides and attacking Carnataurs are obstacles that can set players back. The first player to reach the nesting ground is the winner.

Name: War Tactics or Can Great Britain Be Invaded?
Description:
One of the oldest high level strategy games, War tactics takes place on a map containing England, Denmark, Belgium, Germany and a part of northern France.

The map is divided into a series of squares which include ports, forts towns, cities and the capitals.  Units include land units, dreadnoughts, torpedo boats, cruisers, air units and subs.  Each unit has a different movement pattern (for example ships - dreadnoughts, torpedo boats, cruisers all can move 1 square forward, right or left but not diagonal or backward) and the players try to capture enemy units and ultimately the enemy capital.  Landing on an enemy will capture him.

Players take turns moving units and gain rewards for occupying key sites like naval bases and 1 square of the capital (out of a total of 4).  Scores are gained for occupying towns, cities and naval bases.  At the end of the game the player with the most points wins the game.

Name: Nanaimo World Championship Bathtub Race Game
Description:
GOOD CLEAN FUN

This lively and slightly cutthroat game for two to six players is a tongue-in-cheek, board game version of the renowned Nanaimo World Championship Bathtub Race. An original game created by Games People Played, it is hand-crafted in Nanaimo BC on BC grown and milled Lodgepole Pine.

Name: Game of Siege
Description: Published in Nuremberg around 1830 using lithography, the game features pawns moving for position on a grid overlaid with curving lines.  The board folds in half and the pawns fit inside for storage.  Pictured in the book Games We Play.

Name: Wir Zaubern Mit Buchstaben
Description:
A German language children's game where words are formed by placing letters in designated spaces around the board.

A (very) rough translation of the text on the box:
It's about the sound of letters and the ideas of the other players.  120 letter cards are used to develop and change words by changing or extending existing words.  Children are free to practice using their imagination and vocabulary.

Original German:
Hier geht es um lauter buchstaben und viele einfälle der mitspieler.
Mit 120 buchstabenkärtchen werden wörter aufgebaut und durch ablegen immer wieder so verändert, daß andere daraus entstehen.
Kinder lassen ihrer phantasie freien raum und üben dabel spielerisch ihren wortreichtum.

Name: Cha·Do: Das Tee-Spiel
Description:
A promotional game (subtitled "The Tea Game") based on Alex Randolph's and Michael Matschoss' Enchanted Forest (this is not credited on the box or in the rules; it is obviously produced by Ravensburger though also uncredited).

Dethlefsen & Balk is a tea merchant and so the players travel over a world map where 13 small cardboard tea trees with different symbols on their underside are placed on cities connected to the tea industry.

Players may look under trees and memorize their symbol to collect cards (lying in Hamburg) with the matching symbols.

Some spaces force a player to draw an event card.

Name: Prison
Description:
An abstract game: the 13 red pins are the prisoners, 4 black pins are the wardens. Wardens (starting on each of the four corners of the 8 x 8 board) have to capture the prisoners by jumping over them - if only 3 red pins are remaining, the game  is  won by the warden player.

The red pins try to reach all 4 corner spaces (which is their victory condition).
A warden cannot be eliminated, but is forced to jump over a red pin, if possible.

Name: Army Checkers
Description:
The object of the game is to capture one or more enemy men between two of your men.  Captures may be made along vertical, diagonal or horizontal rows of squares.

On the first turn only, the opening player player places 2 men, 1 on the start in the center of the board and 1 more adjacent.  The other player must then place 2 side by side, adjacent to the first player.  Each player then places a single man next to an enemy man trying to encase them between friendly men.  Any enemy so encased are flipped over to the friendly side.

When maneuvers end the player with the most men showing wins.

Name: Infinite Chess
Description:
A variant form of chess played with the usual pieces on an infinity-symbol-shaped board. While the rules are nearly identical to those of standard chess, the differing topology changes the game substantially.

Original websites for it are no longer up, but the WayBack Machine has a cached version at https://web.archive.org/web/20141017211751/http://www.colebank.com:80/ichess/index.asp

Name: Ísland: spurningaspil
Description:
Ísland - spurningaspil (Iceland) is basically a trivia game with some economic traits, where you travel around Iceland and along the way you can buy and sell properties and build motels and hotels on those properties. Other players pay rent when they land on a property belonging to others.

If you land on a question spot, you have ten seconds to answer the question (six categories), getting a reward if answered correctly, or paying a penalty (money or doing something silly) if getting the answer wrong. Players decide for how long they play, whether for a set period of time or as long it takes to eliminate all the others.

Name: Vogun vinnur, vogun tapar
Description:
This trivia game is based on a popular radio quiz show from the late fifties, aired on the National Broadcasting Corporation of Iceland. The game comes with ten envelopes (categories) containing 20 questions each, with categories like arithmetic puzzles, literature, who advertises like this?, the bible, old Norse religion and more. Also included is a booklet with the answers.

There are two ways to play the game, Double or nothing (where you get 4, 8, 16, 32 or 64 points if you answer the five questions from chosen categorie correctly, or zero points if you answer incorrectly). Another way is Who knows what? where you mix the questions and you get 2 points for correctly answered questions (1 point if you answer a question someone else failed to answer).

Name: All Fall Down
Description:
The exciting race game where players pieces may suddenly disappear with a "plonk".

The game board consists of two layers. The top layer has a race course with hole on each square surrounded by a plastic rim to hold upright the narrow player pawns. The bottom layer is on black card with various holes and sits inside the box. When the upper board is placed on top most squares on the race track have a solid footing for the pawns, but some have holes that allow the pawns to fall through into the box and out of the game. The boards are square so that they can be rotated in relation to each other to provide variable distribution of the holes.

Each player takes 5 pawns. The winner is the first person to get a pawn to the end of the track. Players roll the dice and move one of their pawns the distance indicated. If they have multiple pawns on the track they can chose which one to move. When a hole is discovered by a player losing their piece to it all players need to remember where it is so that they don't repeat the mistake.

Name: Paddelfahrt
Description: Players roll dice to maneuver down the river, poor rolls will trap players in a whirlpool that later rolls will allow them to escape.  The pawns are little metal canoes, each with a canoeist.

Name: Wer hat Vorfahrt?
Description: Pictured in Games We Play, the players move their trucks around the board to the variable fire locations.

Name: The Mountain Race
Description: Children's game in which the pawns are racing cars designed to climb mountains, giving them something of a tractor look.

Name: Holiday Travels
Description: Roll-and-move game featuring train travel in Europe.  Pictured in Games We Play.

Name: Swiss Travels
Description: Players move around Switzerland collecting tokens.  Cards marked 1 through 6 are drawn determing starting positions. typical 'roll&Move' game.

Name: Volando Flying Roulette
Description: This is an odd version of roulette.  A British plane which is on a counter-weighted arm is "flown" in a circle over the playing surface.  Players wager on where the plane will land.  Payoffs are made based on the size of the area.

Name: Stop!
Description: Pictured in Games We Play, this game involves moving your own trucks across a rural map/maze while blocking your opponents passage.

Name: Im Fluge durch Grossdeutschland
Description:
A reworking of classic games of flying around the world, but instead players just move around Germany.  It came out at a time when German planes really couldn't go anywhere with a peaceful landing in mind.

Pictured in the book Games We Play.

Name: Bang!
Description:
A militaristic abstract in which players move three types of pieces: gunners, machine-gunners, and guns," on the grid lines of a checker board that is crossed with diagonal lines.

Pictured in the book Games We Play.  It was one of several militaristically themed games that came out in the run up to WWII.

Name: Roly Poly
Description:
From the publisher:
A novel game with Goblins.  The figures are made to jump into the perforated board with a 5x5 grid.

Pictured in the book Games We Play, from the illustration, one can't figure out if the point is to get the correct hole in the board or avoid the holes in the board.

Name: Nansen's Nordpolfahrt
Description:
One of several roll-and-move games that came out between 1890 and 1910 as the public was enthralled with expeditions to the arctic.

The board features illustrations of the trip north, by ship, kayak, dogsled, and skis.  The dice rolling journey covers the journey north and the return home.

The board is pictured in the book Games We Play.

Name: Star Hopping
Description: Pictured in the book Games We Play, this is a roll and move game played on two stars, one on the inside of each half of a box.  It appears that players collect the tokens put out on each point of the star at the start of the game.

Name: Game of Nuns
Description: Featured in the book Games We Play as an example of an early game from Nuremberg.  The game appears to be a four person game of checkers played on cross with 33 holes, and the playing pieces are pins about the size of golf tees.  The board is actually the lid of a wooden box that holds the pieces.  Unlike other games from this early 1800's Nuremberg period, there is a chance copies of this game exist, even in mint condition, because it looks to be all wood.

Name: Flora, the Flower Game
Description: Featured in the book Games We Play as an example of an early lithograph game published in Nuremberg, from the illustration it appears to be an early version of Tangoes, with red and blue geometric shapes that can be arranged to create "flowers."

Name: New Question and Answer Game
Description: Featured in the book Games We Play, one wonders if this was the first trivia game...but with the word New in the title perhaps it was the second.  From the illustration, it appears that each lithographed card consists of one full-color humorous illustration and one question.

Name: Battle of Talana Hill
Description:
A wargame depicting the Battle of Talana Hill -- October 20, 1899.

A deck of playing cards determines who does what and when (if a red card is drawn, the British player activates one counter. If it is a black card, the Boer player activates one counter.)

Players win by obtaining more victory points than their opponent. Victory points are obtained for inflicting casualties.

Name: Bears, Foxes & Hares
Description:
A game for Icehouse pieces (the rules are written with the Rainbow Treehouse set in mind. If you are using the Xeno set or your own stashes, adjust the color reference accordingly. You will need one pyramid of each size of 5 different colors.)

The animals in different parts of the forest have sent teams to compete in the annual contest. Each team has a grumpy bear, an impatient fox and a nervous hare. They all race to get to the center of the board. Along the way you will have opportunities to push your opponents out of the way, pin them motionless, leap over them, swap places with them and hitch a ride with them.

Name: Miltry
Description: Very little is known about the game.  The box describes it as "A Game of Warring Nations".   The pieces are colored wooden pieces with flags of five countries attached (England, France, Germany, Austria Hungary, Russia).  The game play is point to point with captures happening when there is no place to retreat to and controlled capitals are used to determine winners at the end of the game.

Name: Champion European War Game
Description:
The goal is to see which side can capture the other.  Germany faces England, Belgium, France and Russia in four wars, the side that wins three battles wins the war and is the "Champion".

Each war is fought one at a time.  The opponents each place a unit in the appropriate capital and play is determined by spinning the spinner. If there is a gap between units then the inner circle (movement) is used, otherwise a battle is fought and the outer ring is used.

The player that pushes the enemy army back and captures the enemy fort wins the war.

Name: Battle Zone
Description:
Players roll dice to determine which colored pieces they can activate. When activated, a player can do the following with the piece:

* Place a small piece onto your home row under your control.
  * Upgrade a piece you control or one that is standing.
  * Move a piece you control
  * Activate a lying piece you control by standing it up.
  * Activate a standing piece by downgrading it. Apply area after downgrade.
  * Take control of a standing piece.

If, during play, a piece is moved over and off your opponent's side of the board, place it aside. It is out of play and counts towards your win.

The first player to have a piece of each color cross over and off your opponent’s home row wins.

Name: Dragon Racing
Description:
Players roll dice and assign rolls to Speed, Dexterity (cornering), Fire Breath and Agility (dodging). They then race through a maze with fire breathing combat possibly occurring when two dragons meet.

The Print and Play version of the game can be downloaded from http://www.mmiparchive.papermakeit.com/28%20-%20Boardgames.html

Name: Cooperation: The wealth of Nations Game
Description:
COOPERATION: The Wealth of Nations Game is a boardgame simulating economic systems. It includes four different variants of different skill levels based on different economic systems. BARTER is the beginners' game, MAJORITY RULE is the socialist game, MAKING MONEY is the capitalist game, and AUTONOMY is the expert tournament game.

The game plays up to six players. Each player manages cities. The object of a game is to obtain basic resources for each city while employing the fewest people . Players receive points for each different resource they obtain and bonus points for citizens at leisure.

AUTONOMY simulates a futuristic possible economic system that would produce wealth for everyone with a minimum of work.

The game is based on Information Chain Theory.

In addition to existing as a boardgame, this game is downloadable as an electronic game from the publishers' website.

Name: Minotaur!
Description:
MINOTAUR! is a two-player game based on Greek Mythology.

Every year, by the decree of King Minos, fourteen Athenians are selected to be sacrificed to Asterion the Minotaur in the labyrinth at Knossos.

Players take on the role of the final two Athenians trapped in the labyrinth.

MINOTAUR! features a dynamic game board and affords players the opportunity to take control of the minotaur, all in an effort to be the last Athenian to survive.

Name: Panko or Votes for Women
Description:
This card game from 1910 shows pictures of events happening in the suffrage "Votes for Woman" era. I don't know much more about the game except that a copy of it is in The Jon A. Lindseth Suffrage Collection.

The card game had set of 52 cards and features Emmeline Pankhurst and Winston Churchill. The cards are purple, green, and white. The game instructions were included in the box.

Name: 5.56mm
Description:
25/28mm modern skirmish system.  Rules cover infantry and vehicles.  Players are intended to use about a squad each.

The game relies on a card based activation system - each character is assigned a card and activates when it is drawn.  Elite characters get a second card but receive fewer actions when it comes up.

Task rolls are done with a single six-sided die and generally scale by distance.  Better trained characters receive a larger bonus to their tests.

Damage is an opposed roll (damage versus strength) and can inflict death or one of several wound states.  Wounds reduce movement and penalize a character on skill tests.

The morale rules are tucked away in the back of the rules, but boil down to checking morale for certain casualty-based triggers.

The rulebook does not provide a points or scenario system, though there is a system for generating squads.  Wargames Journal has published at least one scenario for the game as a free PDF download.

Name: Ballot Bots
Description: You are a politician, and your position in the race depends on your ability to fund raise, advertise, debate and speak to your contingency at the right time and place. Advance your campaign, solidify your position, put yourself in the spotlight as you strategically maneuver around your opponents!

Name: Dubious
Description: du-bi-ous. (adjective) of doubtful quality or propriety; questionable. What's hotter: A fish on a grill, androgynous business women, or a fire breathing alligator? Which is more dangerous: Sky diving, a hair dryer, or a dinosaur? You and your friends make snap judgments and questionable comparisons in an attempt to earn points in an escalating betting system.

Name: Connecto
Description:
(Translated from the box in Norwegian)

A different trivia game!

What is missing in the statement?

You will be presented song lyrics, titles, rankings, quotes, sayings and abbreviations where one, two or three words are missing, depending on level of difficulty.
You do not pick categories, so general knowledge is gold. 
You may win 250 000 quite fast by gambling at difficulty level 3, but arrogance might bring you down, and you may fast descent to bankruptcy if the gambler in you takes the upper hand.
You have to position yourself on the board, use tactical maneuvers and be on guard, so your opponents do not bluff when they say they want to help you. Logic is a handy tool, but will not help if you are totally blank on song lyrics. Your opponents are ready to help, but can you trust them?

The game Connecto gives you a chance to shine with knowledge you did not even know you possessed. Let yourself get carried away with song lyrics and do deep dives into logical rows of numbers.
Place countries correctly by area and refresh the sayings you thought you had forgotten. 
Will you be the first player to reach 250 000?

Name: Race to the Fairy Castle
Description: Race to the Fairy Castle is a simple roll and move game from Chad Valley. The object of the game is to reach the Fairy Castle, the ultimate destination for each player,  by getting past dragons, goblins, fiery serpents, wolves and The Black Knight!!

Name: Fun with the Pepper Family
Description: Fun with the Pepper Family was made by Chad Valley in the mid 1920's. The game consists of a story being read with players, on their turn, adding words in order to fill in the blanks so that the story is completed. Votes are taken on if the word fits the storyline.

Name: Banana Split
Description:
In Banana Split, you want to complete as many ice cream orders as can, especially the valuable banana splits! To set up the game, shuffle the ice cream order deck, then reveal four cards. Shuffle the ingredient deck, and deal each player five cards, which they place behind their screens. On a turn, a player can:


    Draw one card from the ingredient deck.
    Take one ice cream order and play ingredients on it.
    Add one or more ingredient cards to an order already in front of you.


When you play ingredients on an order, you must play exactly as many as are on the card and in the order listed, from top to bottom. When you play the final ingredient on an order, place that card aside as you'll score its point value at the end of the game. Banana split orders can't be built upon turn by turn, but must be claimed all in one go, either by playing all four ingredients at the same time or discarding one wild card ingredient. Special ingredient cards let you steal an ice cream order in progress or take an extra turn.

Once all the ice cream orders have been fulfilled, players tally their scores to see who wins.

Name: The Cleveland Second Term Puzzle Game
Description: The object of the Cleveland Second Term Puzzle is to navigate wooden balls through a wood and metal maze into the “President’s room.” This game was issued during Grover Cleveland’s 1892 re-election campaign. A copy of this game is in the Susan H. Douglas Political Americana Collection.

Name: Pinocchio Race Game
Description: This simple roll and move game is probably from the early to the mid 1950's. Game comes with a die, playing pieces and a board with spaces numbered 1 to 120. The board has a couple of detours that might have to be taken on the way to the finish line.

Name: Le Jeu Du Dictionnaire
Description: This game teaches French. Each player takes a turn by using a dictionary (2 are included in the game) to pick a word based on a card that the player has drawn from a card deck. He tells it out loud, without spelling it. Anyone who can spell the word correctly  wins extra points at the end of the round. The dictionary holder writes down the definition on his paper. Each player must then write the correct spelling of the word and a definition for the word.  Even if the player does not know the definition of the word, he must bluff one that will be the most believable.  All sheets are then turned over to the dictionary holder so that he can number them and mix them up. Then he will read each definition out loud. He is allowed to repeat them up to 3 times.  Then everyone votes for the definition they think is the right one!  Points are given for getting the right spelling of the word, and for every vote each player got etc. The first player to reach 40 points  is declared the winner!

Name: Days of Empire: Rules for Wargaming the Crimean War, 1854-1856
Description:
These miniatures rules were designed specifically for the Crimean War period.

Days of Empire is a set of rules for 18mm wargaming. Cavalry and Infantry are represented by stands 50 of men. Artillery, Engineers and Staff are represented by stands of 10 men.  An artillery gun model represents two actual guns.

Name: Kipin Kapin Kurre
Description: Each player has a squirrel with a wheelbarrow, trying to get to the island and pick up nuts that match his cards. By rolling a die, players move their squirrels and also the bridges leading to the island. When a squirrel reaches the island, it gets to pick up nuts from the tree. After picking up a maximum of two nuts the squirrel has to run back home to store the nuts. First player to collect five nuts that match his cards wins.

Name: Gotcher
Description: The gameboard is made of molded plastic and consists of raised islands connected by a series of raised paths. Some paths allow two-way traffic; other only allow one-way traffic. Players choose to be either hunters or fugitives. The object for the fugitives is to make their way across the gameboard. The hunters are trying to capture the fugitives before they reach their objective. In turn, the players advance one of their pawns the number of spaces generated by a Traka, an electronic number generator included with the game.

Name: Traka
Description: An electronic number generator that comes packaged with sixteen games designed for it. The device has eight light-emitting diodes, numbered one through eight, which flash one at a time. The operator of the device presses a button to freeze the flashing to generate a number. A switch can alter the speed of the flashing to either fast or slow.

Name: Pro Patria! Rules for Wargaming in the Age of Napoleon
Description:
These miniatures rules were designed to be both simple and realistic.

Pro Patrica! is a set of rules for 15mm and 25/28mm wargaming. Cavalry and Infantry are represented by stands 50 of men. Artillery, Engineers and Staff are represented by stands of 10 men. An artillery gun model represents two actual guns.

Name: Pro Gloria! Rules for Wargaming in the 18th century
Description:
These miniatures rules were designed to be both simple and realistic.

Pro Gloria! is a set of rules for 15mm abd 25/28mm wargaming. Cavalry and Infantry are represented by stands 50 of men. Artillery, Engineers and Staff are represented by stands of 10 men. An artillery gun model represents two actual guns.
Families: History: War of the Spanish Succession

Name: Days of Glory: Rules for Wargaming the American Civil War
Description:
These miniatures rules were designed specifically for the American Civil War period.

Days of Glory is a set of rules for 15mm wargaming at the regimental scale. Cavalry and Infantry stands represent 50 men each. Artillery, Engineers and Staff stand represent 10 men each.  An artillery gun represents two actual guns.
